title: How to Navigate the Digestive Side Effects of GLP-1 Medications

content: A friend of mine recently went to the ER with her mother-in-law, who’d been vomiting for two days. At the hospital, she was diagnosed with gastroparesis, a digestive disorder that happens when the stomach empties so slowly that it triggers abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Turns out she was taking a GLP-1 agonist to treat diabetes and obesity. Partly, these medications work by slowing down stomach emptying, which creates a feeling of fullness that can help you eat less and lose weight.

But people taking these medications also have a higher risk of gastroparesis, which affects the nerves and muscles of the stomach and can cause serious complications like dehydration and malnutrition.

Currently, about 1 in 8 people in the U.S. are taking a GLP-1 medication. The medications have been shown to help you lose up to 20% of your body weight, which can improve your health in dramatic ways. The drugs may even help quiet cravings for drinking alcohol and smoking.

content: GI-related issues are the most common side effect of these drugs. For some, these side effects are mild, occurring temporarily when the medication is started and each time it’s increased. For others – like my friend’s mother-in-law – they’re bad enough that the medication needs to be stopped altogether.
If you’re taking a GLP-1 or considering it, here are the most common digestive side effects, plus what you can do to help prevent them or feel better in the moment:

Constipation is a possible side effect of a number of medications, including GLP-1s. Diet changes related to taking the medication – such as eating less or eating different foods – can also cause irregularity.

Most people on GLP-1 medications have heard about the importance of eating plenty of protein to prevent the loss of muscle along with weight. But in a survey by Eat Well Global of people taking GLP-1 medications, only about half said they were eating a high-fiber diet.

Eating fiber is key to preventing constipation – both foods rich in soluble fiber (like oats, beans, and whole grains) and insoluble fiber (like leafy greens, berries, and seeds). Drinking plenty of fluids, which helps your stools move more easily, is critical, too.

content: Since these medicines target the appetite, it might be hard to eat enough food to get adequate fiber. If that’s the case, a fiber supplement might be needed. Physical activity can also help keep things moving.

GLP-1 medications help make you feel full in part because they slow down how quickly the stomach empties. But slow gastric emptying can cause nausea. Trying to eat when you physically don’t feel hungry may lead to queasiness, too.
If you’re used to eating three meals a day, switch to smaller portions more often so there’s less in your stomach at one time. Eat more slowly, and stop when you notice you’re full.

Though less common, diarrhea can occur with GLP-1 medicines, often in the first four weeks of treatment. To manage diarrhea, drink lots of fluids to prevent dehydration, but avoid soda, coffee, and alcohol. Steering clear of sugar alcohols (they usually end in “ol,” as in “sorbitol”) can help, too.

content: For many people, side effects will taper over time and go away. But if your GI side effects aren’t getting better, talk to your doctor about decreasing your dose, stopping the medication, or trying a different medication.
More severe digestive-related side effects are less common but can happen. These include not only gastroparesis but also bowel obstruction.
